July 29, 2001: Fiction
THE FOURTH HAND, by John Irving. (Random House, $26.95.) Life takes
unusual turns for a New York television reporter whose left hand is eaten by a
circus lion in India.
ANY WAY THE WIND BLOWS, by E. Lynn Harris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A
Broadway star seeks a measure of revenge on the man who left her at the altar; a
sequel to "Not a Day Goes By."
CANE RIVER, by Lalita Tademy. (Warner, $24.95.) The story of four generations
of African-American women, from 1834 to 1936.
LEAP OF FAITH, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Upon returning to the
French chateau of her childhood, a woman encounters new love and mortal
danger.
"P" IS FOR PERIL, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/ Putnam, $26.95.) The
California private eye Kinsey Millhone searches for a prominent specialist in
geriatric medicine who has gone missing.
SEVEN UP, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Stephanie Plum, a New
Jersey bounty hunter, is assigned the task of finding a semiretired mobster.
THE JURY, by Steve Martini. (Putnam, $25.95.) The lawyer-sleuth Paul Madriani
represents an important medical researcher who has been charged with the
murder of a young colleague.
A TRAITOR TO MEMORY, by Elizabeth George. (Bantam, $26.95.) A detective
inspector investigates the hit-and-run killing of a woman on a London street.
THE WIND DONE GONE, by Alice Randall. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.) A parodic
sequel to "Gone With the Wind" in which the heroine is Scarlett O'Hara's half
sister, a slave.
RISE TO REBELLION, by Jeff Shaara. (Ballantine, $26.95.) From the Boston
Massacre to the signing of the Declaration of Independence: the first volume of a
novel about the American Revolution.
HOLLYWOOD WIVES -- The New Generation, by Jackie Collins. (Simon &
Schuster, $26.) The loves and ruthless ambitions of women in today's Hollywood.
BACK WHEN WE WERE GROWNUPS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $25.) A 53-year-
old woman, the head of an unruly extended family in Baltimore, tries to recover her
"original self."
DEAD SLEEP, by Greg Iles. (Putnam, $19.95.) A photojournalist, at the urging of
the F.B.I., struggles to resolve the mystery behind her sister's disappearance.
Non-Fiction
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of
the country's first vice president and second president.
STOLEN LIVES, by Malika Oufkir and Mich√®le Fitoussi. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion,
$24.) A Moroccan woman recalls the 20 years she spent in a desert jail.
GHOST SOLDIERS, by Hampton Sides. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The story of a
United States Army plan to rescue prisoners of war (including survivors of the
Bataan death march) in the Philippines in early 1945.
FOUNDING BROTHERS, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.) A historian's study of
the intertwined lives of the nation's founders.
THE TRUTH IS . . . , by Melissa Etheridge with Laura Morton. (Villard, $24.95.)
The autobiography of the rock star.
JUSTICE, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $24.) A collection of essays about crimes
and criminals, trials and punishments.
NAPALM & SILLY PUTTY, by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The comedian
offers opinions on everything from God to pets to the Lone Ranger.
SUPREME INJUSTICE, by Alan M. Dershowitz. (Oxford University, $25.) The
Harvard law professor argues that the Supreme Court "hijacked" the 2000
presidential election.
THE NOONDAY DEMON, by Andrew Solomon. (Scribner, $28.) A personal,
cultural and scientific survey of depression.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of the
horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with War Admiral.
THE BOTANY OF DESIRE, by Michael Pollan. (Random House, $24.95.) How the
angiosperms (the flowering plants) have prospered by seducing other creatures,
including humans.
AN ALBUM OF MEMORIES, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $29.95.) More
personal histories from members of "the greatest generation."
CLOSE TO SHORE, by Michael Capuzzo. (Broadway, $24.95.) A journalist's
account of the hunt for a great white shark that attacked five people at the Jersey
Shore in 1916.
